intro: Ageratum oerstedii, commonly known as the Mexican blue mistflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, blue to purple flower heads. The plant typically grows as an upright annual or perennial, reaching heights of up to 3 feet, with hairy stems and narrow, gray-green leaves. Its flowers are composed of two types of florets—ray florets that form the outer petals and disc florets that make up the central cone. Ageratum oerstedii is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a cut flower due to its striking color and compact growth habit.
